description.narrative: 1. Building and equipping of the CMP anthropological laboratory 2. Numbers of new remains of missing persons exhumed, analyzed and returned to their relatives

comment.narrative: A total of 502 Turkish Cypriots and 1493 Greek Cypriots were officially reported as missing by both communities. CMP's objective is to exhume, identify and return remains of people listed as missing to their families.
Contributing to the results set for the CMP-7.
Achieved.

title.narrative: New Nicosia Waste Water Treatment Plant

description.narrative: The project for the new Nicosia Waste Water Treatment Plant aims to promote and facilitate access to wastewater services to both communities of Nicosia as a fundamental contribution to the on-going peace and confidence building process.

title.narrative: Project Document of "New Nicosia Waste Water Treatment Plant"

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building is either recognized or led by national authorities
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building brings the conflict parties into a process to dialogue the issues at stake
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building conducts regular inclusive consultations

The project for the new Nicosia Waste Water Treatment Plant (NWWTP) aims to promote and facilitate access to waste water services to both communities of Nicosia as a fundamental contribution to the on-going peace and confidence building process.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: 1. Old and overloaded waste water treatment plant; 2. No joint entity between the two communities exists
Defect Liability period
Defect Liability period ongoing
Complete closure of the contract / Transition into phase 2 and financial project closure

UNDP 2016 goal to close the contract for Phase 1 of the project was not achieved. The plant has been operational since 2012. A Taking Over certificate was issued for Phase 1 in June 2013 prior to the following 12 months Defects Notification Period and commencement of Phase 2 but difficulties arise in the non-performance of the sludge treatment plant which so far have precluded the issue of the final Performance Certificate and release of the Performance Security for Phase 1. Phase 1 of the Contract provides for “Damages for Failure to meet the Performance Guarantees” and hence making the appropriate contractual deductions would enable the Performance Certificate for Phase 1 to be issued and the Phase 1 Performance Security to be released. At the request of the EC a process engineer has been recruited to assess the reasons for the failure to meet guaranteed biogas production.

Complete closure of the contract / Transition into phase 2 and financial project closure
T1. Preparation and presentation to the Project Board of an assessment report on the current situation of the Waste Water Treatment Plant prepared by the process engineer Identification of the necessary remedies and costing in order to close Phase 1 contract Calculation of the damages for the non-performance of the sludge. Preparation of a roadmap of the necessary action to be taken by Phase 2 Employer.
T2. Based on the outputs of the process engineer report, details to agree on the transitioning of the failed biogas production to the Phase 2 thus protecting the Phase 2 employers when the plant reverts to them in 2023.
T3. Issuing the Performance Certificate and making all necessary contractual actions to close the Phase 1 contract, I.e. making the final payment and releasing the bank guarantee and receiving the signed discharge by the contractor; by the end of the year.

A process engineer has carried out his reviews and submitted reports.
Meetings have been held with the PB and the contractor. An agreement has been reached to close Phase 1 and transition into Phase 2 with a safeguard of Euro 4.75 meuro.
The project has been extended to 30 December 2017.

description.narrative: This project aims at contributing to the confidence building process through the preservation of Cypriot cultural heritage island wide according to the strategy of the Technical Committee on Cultural Heritage.

independent political entity

1. Number of cultural heritage sites kept safe in order to avoid further decline and collapses 2. Number of completion ceremonies organised, communication updates issued, success stories disseminated.

comment.narrative: 11 Cultural Heritage sites selected within the agreed Technical Committee on Cultural Heritage bi-communal list. Selected cultural heritage sites in derelict conditions.

T1 - At least 3 conservation works completed and project completion ceremonies organized. Bi-communal monitoring visits to project sites are organized and facilitated regularly (at least one every two months)
T2 - At least 4 completion ceremony organised, 4 press releases issued, at least one social media post per project and 2 success stories published.

T1 - Achieved: 4 conservation works completed in Philia/Serhatköy - Profitis Elias Church / Melandrina Church in Agios Amvrosios/Esentepe / Evretou/Evretu - Mosque / Cherkezoi/Cerkez – Mosque.
T2 Achieved: 5 project completion ceremonies organized bringing together Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots in Othello Tower in Famagusta (July 2015), Paphos Hamam (March 2015), Evretou/Evretu Mosque (March 2015), Tzerkezoi/Cerkez Mosque (March 2015), Profitis Elia Church in Philia/Serhatkoy (17 November 2015) / 18 Press releases issued and 4 Media Advisories / 72 posts have been published on UNDP Cyprus Facebook page and 70 Tweets have been published on Twitter. - 1 success story published on UNDP CY website, 1 blog article published on UNDP RBEC website. 118 media articles on GC and TC newspapers covering CH1 projects.

T1 - 2 conservation works started (Martinengo Bastion and Walls between Othello and Arsenal
T2 - At least 4 press releases issued

T1 - Conservation works started at Martinengo Bastion and Walls between Othello and Arsenal - projects ongoing
T2 - 13 CH1 related posts published on UNDP Cyprus social media / 4 press releases issued / 1 open meeting to present upcoming projects was held in Famagusta on 14 July 2016.

T1 - 2 conservation works at Martinengo Bastion and Walls between Othello and Arsenal completed
T2 - 1 project completion ceremony held, at least 2 press releases issued, 1 community meeting with civil society organisation organised in Famagusta, one semi-permanent exhibition prepared, 1 video issued and disseminated.

T1 - Conservation works at Martinengo Bastion and Walls between Othello and Arsenal completed
T2 - 1 project completion ceremony held, at least 2 press releases issued, 1 community meeting with civil society organisation organised in Famagusta, one semi-permanent exhibition prepared, 1 video issued and disseminated.

comment.narrative: Study of Cultural Heritage Support to cultural heritage monuments of great importance for Cyprus - Phase 1 List of sites identified by the strategy note of the Technical Committee on Cultural Heritage

T1- Bi-communal monitoring visits to project sites organised and facilitated regularly (at least one per month) T2 - Conservation works completed in at least 2 cultural heritage sites T3 - Tendering process completed for conservation works at Agios Panteleimonas Monastery T4. At least 1 events/completion ceremonies organised, 1 press releases issued, one post per project on undp cyprus social media.

T1- Achieved: One bi-communal monitoring visits/month organised T2 - Achieved: Conservation works completed in Agios Afksentios Church (May 2015), Old St.George Church (14 November 2015), Watermill/Aqueduct in Chrysochou/Hirsofu (Expected completion date: December 2015) T3 - Tendering process completed for conservation works at Agios Panteleimonas Monastery. T4 - 2 completion ceremonies organised (Agios Afksentios and Old St.George church / on average 5 cultural heritage-related updates per month were published on UNDP-PFF social media and 1 news article per month on UNDP-PFF website / One new 20-pages brochure was printed in February 2015 and disseminated in 5,000 copies / 1 tour presentation at Othello, Ravelin, Martinengo & Famagusta Walls was carried out on the occasion of the International Day of Monuments and Sites on 18 April 2015 / 2 presentations on the work of the TCCH were delivered to visiting international students / 2 presentations on the work of the TCCH were delivered by the TCCH Representatives in different Cypriot universities.

T1. At least 1 conservation works completed. T2. 1 surveys and technical project design completed. T3. At least 7 Small Project Activities (SPA) completed. T4. At least 1 events/completion ceremonies organised, 1 press releases issued, one post per project on undp cyprus social media.

T1. 1 conservation works completed (Agios Panteleimonas Monastery)
T2. 1 surveys and technical project designs ongoing (Kyrenia Shipwreck gallery upgrading)
T3. 7 Small Project Activities (SPA) completed (Agios Andonios in Masari / Sahinler, Agios Andonios in Kythrea / Değirmenlik, Agios Charalambos in Akanthou/Tatlisu, Agios Demetrios in Leonarisso/Ziyamet, Archangelos Michael in Aigialousa/Yenierenköy, Agios Sozomenos in Davlos/Kaplıca, Agios Thereseon (Therapon) in Angastina/Aslanköy).
T4 - 1 completion ceremony organised (Watermill-Aqueduct in Chrisochou/Hirsofu) / 23 cultural heritage 2 -related updates published on UNDP social media during 2016 / One new 50-pages brochure designed and ready for printing / 3 tour presentation at Agios Panteleimonas Monastery were organised for journalists, university students and general public on the occasion of the International Day of Monuments and Sites on 18 April 2016 / 2 presentations on the work of the TCCH were delivered to visiting international students / 2 presentations on the work of the TCCH were delivered by the TCCH Representatives in different Cypriot universities / 2 videos produced / 37 articles appeared on both communities newspaper covering CH2 projects in 2016.
T2. 1 surveys and technical project design completed. T3. At least 3 Small Project Activities (SPA) completed.
T2. Conservation designs for the Kyrenia Shipwreck Gallery upgarding completed. T3. Small Project Activities in Mathiatis mosque, Tophane Mosque, Köprülü Mosque completed.

title.narrative: Restoration of the Holy Monastery of Apostolos Andreas

description.narrative: The restoration of this very important religious monument intends to contribute to the on-going confidence-building process between the Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots communities within the context of cultural heritage preservation and protection.

title.narrative: Project Document_Restoration of Apostolos Andreas Monastery

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building is either recognized or led by national authorities
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building brings the conflict parties into a process to dialogue the issues at stake
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building conducts regular inclusive consultations
Peacebuilding and reconciliation processes reinforced through the restoration of the Monastery of Apostolos Andreas, one of Cyprus most iconic heritage site.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Restoration of the Church & the adjacent buildings completed 2. Iconostasis and other immovable objects which are an inherent part of the church restored. 3. Geotechnical investigations & tests carried out. 4. Number of press releases issued, number of newspaper articles covering the project, number of videos produced.

comment.narrative: The project will be implemented according to the project prepared by the University of Patras in 2007.

T1. At least 60% of restoration completed Supervision of works according to contract conditions/to carry out the necessary inspections of the Civil Works/ testing and acceptance Bi-communal site visits organized on quarterly basis
T3. A detailed geotechnical investigation is carried out on the east side of the Apostolos Andreas Monastery to determine geological, geotechnical and mechanical properties of the soil strata on which the chapel is situated.
T4. At least one bi-communal media site visit organized. At least 2 social media posts on works progress.At least 1 press release issued.
All Achieved.

T1. Complete restoration of the main church complex T2 Conservation of the icons, iconostasis, ambon and altar by bi-communal teams composed of Turkish Cypriot archaeologist/conservator, and Greek Cypriot specialised conservators. T3. Completion event organised / at least 1 press release issued, one bi-communal media site visit organised / 1 video produced.

T1. Completion of conservation works to the main church complex.
T2. The main church’s iconostasis, 58 religious icons, the Ambon and the Holy Altar have been conserved.
T3. Completion event organised on 07 November 2016. The church was consecrated on 18 November 2016 and approximately 2000 people attended the first religious ceremony held on 29 November 2016 after completion of the conservation project. Ever since, religious ceremonies have been held at Apostolos Andreas Monastery monthly with an increasing visitation of both Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots. 200 newspaper articles covering the various phases of the project were published on main local newspapers. 4 social media posts published on UNDP CY facebook page / 1 video produced / 1 semi-permanent exhibition installed.

Designers contracted by the Church to complete the designs, specifications and the drawings for the subsequent phases. UNDP to tender for the works for the subsequent phases. Contracting for the works Amendment of the PD to extend duration to cover the works of the subsequent phases
Partially received the documents but not in full for tendering.

Support to the Committee on Missing Persons' Project on Exhumation, Identification and Return of Remains of Missing Persons in Cyprus, Phase VIII
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots scientists (anthropologists, archaeologists, geologist, psychologists, team leaders, field coordinators, lab coordinators, DNA specialist/geneticists, investigators, photographers, staff, bulldozer drivers and health safety and environment coordinator) working together at burial sites located all over the island in order to exhume human remains and at the CMP Anthropological Laboratory carrying out anthropological analysis of the remains under the coordination of two Cypriot Team Leaders. 2. Number of missing persons returned to their relatives from the total number of 2001 missing from both communities 3. Number of suspected burial sites identified through CMP investigations. 4. Number of days of excavation works (digging of wells, trenching, sieving) carried out. 5. Number of bones/bone fragments handled at the CMP Anthropological Laboratory. 6. Number of bone samples cut by the CMP Anthropological Laboratory and sent to the DNA Laboratory. 7. Number of awareness activities, training, events organised.

comment.narrative: CMP (EC-7)

26 Greek Cypriots and 30 Turkish Cypriots scientists (anthropologists, archaeologists, geologist, psychologists, geneticists, investigators, photographers, workers and bulldozer drivers) working together at burial sites located all over the island in order to exhume human remains and at the CMP Anthropological Laboratory carrying out anthropological analysis of the remains under the coordination of two Cypriot Team Leaders.
60 missing persons returned to their relatives from the total number of 2001 missing from both communities.
40 new suspected burial sites will have been identified through CMP investigations.
150 days of excavation works (digging of wells, trenching, sieving) have been carried out.
80 bones/bone fragments will have been handled at the CMP Anthropological Laboratory.
400 bone samples will have been cut by the CMP Anthropological Laboratory and sent to the DNA Laboratory.
CMP website is maintained to keep the general public and the families informed.
Regular and/or ad hoc audits / reviews of the CMP program and on-site training of CMP scientists by consultants/experts (for example, geneticists specialised in mass disasters and /or degraded DNA, archaeologists and forensic anthropologists).
Participation of CMP scientists (anthropologists, archaeologists, geneticists) in specialised trainings abroad.
Operations staff recruited by UNDP.

115 missing persons returned to their relatives from the total number of 2001 missing from both communities.
More than 26 Greek Cypriots and 30 Turkish Cypriots scientists (anthropologists, archaeologists, geologist, psychologists, geneticists, investigators, photographers, workers and bulldozer drivers) working together at burial sites located all over the island in order to exhume human remains and at the CMP Anthropological Laboratory carrying out anthropological analysis of the remains under the coordination of two Cypriot Team Leaders.
More than 40 new suspected burial sites will have been identified through CMP investigations.
More than 150 days of excavation works (digging of wells, trenching, sieving) have been carried out.
More than 80 bones/bone fragments will have been handled at the CMP Anthropological Laboratory.
More than 400 bone samples will have been cut by the CMP Anthropological Laboratory and sent to the DNA Laboratory.
CMP website is maintained to keep the general public and the families informed.
Regular and/or ad hoc audits / reviews of the CMP program and on-site training of CMP scientists by consultants/experts (for example, geneticists specialised in mass disasters and /or degraded DNA, archaeologists and forensic anthropologists).
Participation of CMP scientists (anthropologists, archaeologists, geneticists) in specialised trainings abroad.
Operations staff recruited by UNDP.

28 Greek Cypriots and 31 Turkish Cypriots scientists (anthropologists, archaeologists, geologist, psychologists, team leaders, field coordinators, lab coordinators, DNA specialist/geneticists, investigators, photographers, staff, bulldozer drivers and health safety and environment coordinator) working together at burial sites located all over the island in order to exhume human remains and at the CMP Anthropological Laboratory carrying out anthropological analysis of the remains under the coordination of two Cypriot Team Leaders.
60 missing persons returned to their relatives from the total number of 2001 missing from both communities.
40 new suspected burial sites will have been identified through CMP investigations.
150 days of excavation works (digging of wells, trenching, sieving) have been carried out.
Bones/bone fragments of at least 60 individuals will have been handled at the CMP Anthropological Laboratory.
400 bone samples will have been cut by the CMP Anthropological Laboratory and sent to the DNA Laboratory.
CMP website is maintained to keep the general public and the families informed.
Regular and/or ad hoc audits / reviews of the CMP program and on-site training of CMP scientists by consultants/experts (for example, geneticists specialised in mass disasters and /or degraded DNA, archaeologists and forensic anthropologists).
Participation of CMP scientists (anthropologists, archaeologists, geneticists) in specialised trainings abroad.
Operations staff recruited by UNDP

comment.narrative: Support to monuments of great importance to Cyprus - Phase I and Support to monuments of great importance to Cyprus - Phase III.
Establishment of project team
project team established

T1 A comprehensive framework to ensure adequate caretaking, maintenance and use to all EU funded projects is designed, adopted and started its implementation. 4 letters for maintenance and upkeep responsibility undertaking received by local authorities
T2 8 sites identified to benefit from designs for the conservation projects, and preliminary assessment completed for 6 projects ( Canbulat bastion in Famagusta, Panagia church in Askeia/Pasakoy, Agios Andronikos in Kythrea/Degirmenlik, Agios Artemon in Afanteia/Gazikoy,Old Turkish Cypriot school in Kotsiatis/Koccat,Hamam in Limassol), project design completed for 1 project (Agia Marina church).
T3 2 conservation project started (Archangelos Michael Church and Karpasha/Karpasa Church)
T4 - 9 press releases/media advisories issued - 1 media site visit organized on 09.12.2016 to Paphos Hamam and Minaret of Cami-i Kebir (Ktima) - 22 Facebook posts - One 60 pages brochure on the work of the TCCH designed - 2 newsletters - 4 open-to-the-public informative events organized (2 Archangelos Michael, 1 Paphos, and 1 Famagusta). - 2 university presentations carried out on 19.02.2016 and 12.05.2016.

Opening of new civilian crossings in Cyprus
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
1. Number of road works designs completed 2. Number of road works completed 3. Number of press releases issued, completion/visibility ceremonies organised / media articles etc.

comment.narrative: Existing old roads that have not been used by public traffic since 1974.
Establishment of project team Launch of tender for road designs
Project team established Tender launched.

T1 Project designs for the two roads will be completed. One procurement process will be undertaken / 1 or 2 contracts will be signed for the designs. 2 designs will be completed.
T2 commencement of road works in Derineia/Derinya and Lefka/Lefke
T3 At least 2 press releases issued.

T1. 2 surveys, investigations, tests and project designs completed. 1 Procurement process undertaken. 1 contract signed
T2. Works ongoing at Derineia/Derinya and Lefka/Lefke (2 Procurement process undertaken / 2 contract signed).
T3 3 press releases issued / 3 communication updates posted on social media. Due to the very sensitive political nature of the project and delays from local authorities to implement their obligations, UNDP in full consultation with the European Commission, Technical Committee on Crossings and UNFICYP adopted a low profile in these phases of the project implementation and limit public communications regarding the projects to essential ones (launch of tenders and contract signature).
T2 Works for Derineia/Derinya will be completed in early 2017. Works for Lefka/Lefke will be completed in early 2017.
T2. Derineia/derinya works substantially completed in February 2017 Lefka/Lefke works substantially completed in April 2017

comment.narrative: Current support provided to the Committee on Missing Persons in Cyprus and past support provided by UNDP to OSASG.
T1. At least 5 UN staffing gaps are filled T2. At least 3 brief written reports on the outcomes of consultants' work submitted

T1 Five (5) UN staffing gaps filled: 2 media analysts, 2 governance and power sharing consultants, 1 economic issues consultant recruited.
T2 Three (3) reports submitted by consultants upon their 1st mission to Cyprus

T1. At least 3 new UN staffing gaps are filled T2. At least 10 brief written reports on the outcomes of consultants' work submitted T3. At least 4 OSASG staff report on the support the consultants provided to OSASG. T4. At least 1 burial sites located and excavated T5. At least 20 remains located and exhumed T6. At least 15 identified individuals returned to their families T7. At least 180 reports of social media analysis highlighting public sentiment and communication opportunities T8. At least 4 OSASG, UNFICYP self-report on actions taken following review of social media analysis.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building is either recognized or led by national authorities
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building brings the conflict parties into a process to dialogue the issues at stake
national mechanism for mediation and consensus building conducts regular inclusive consultations
Confidence building through cultural heritage conservation in Cyprus - Phase 5
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: As of December 2016, 15 heritage sites islandwide had been conserved, structurally supported, physically protected or restored. Six are undergoing restoration. Another 20 are under study and will benefit from similar interventions in the near future. 16 sites benefited/will benefit from Small Project Activities (SPA). In total more than 60 heritage sites islandwide are benefiting from the Technical Committee on Cultural Heritage’s work.
Project Document signed Establishment of Project Team
Project Document signed Project Team established

T1. At least 5 conservation projects completed: - Project 1. Conservation works at the Ravelin (Land Gate) - Project 2. Carmelite (St Mary of Carmel) church - Project 3. Mosque in Agios Nicolaos/Aynikola - Project 4. Mosque in Agios Ioannis/Ayanni - Project 5. Minaret of Cami Kebir in Paphos
At least 2 conservation projects started and to be completed in 2018 - Project 6. St. Anne in Famagusta - Project 7. Minaret of Tanner mosque in Famagusta
T.2. At least 2 informative seminars are organised in local communities at the start-up of new projects as well as 2 informative presentation to local universities.
T.3. At least 2 designs for conservation works completed.
T4. At least 5 completion ceremonies organised and 1 event organised on the occasion of the International Day for Monuments and Sites
T5. At least 5 press releases issued
T6. At least 5 media site visits organised
T7. At least 24 social media posts (2 posts per month) on the work of the TCCH
T8. At least 1 publication produced on the work of the TCCH
T9. At least 2 videos produced on the work of TCCH.
